Award.AwardTitle: Neurophysiological circuits underlying episodic memory formation in the human brain

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning and memory formation play a central role in our everyday lives. The critical nature of our ability to acquire new information and to remember previous events is manifested in a variety of conditions that affect memory ranging from learning deficits in children all the way to Alzheimer's disease and related conditions in the elderly. Previous studies have shown that the hippocampus and related structures in the medial temporal lobe (MTL) play a critical role in memory formation for places, images or words. Less is known about how spatiotemporal sequences and events are encoded and recalled. By using movies as a proxy to real-life memory formation for episodic events. Dr. Gabriel Kreiman at the Children's Hospital, Harvard Medical School, will investigate how neuronal activity in the human MTL support the formation of episodic memories during movie events and how the hippocampus interacts with neocortical areas and the amygdala during learning. Computer vision and machine learning techniques will be used to develop detailed annotations of movie events to characterize each sequence of frames in terms of its low-level properties, high-level content and emotional aspects and to predict memory formation for episodic events from audiovisual and emotional content. Furthermore, the researchers will combine this machine learning approach with neurophysiological recordings in the MTL of patients with epilepsy to understand how episodic memories for short movie events are encoded and recalled.

Advancing our understanding of the neural circuits and interactions that orchestrate memory formation will pave the way towards developing innovative technologies to directly interact with the human MTL to enhance learning of everyday episodic information. The machine learning approach used here to characterize recall of complex audio-visual events will provide systematic metrics to make predictions about memory formation, therefore holding the promise of predicting recall in educational settings. Studying how hippocampal neurons participate in the encoding and recall of episodic events is likely to have major clinical implications for understanding and developing interventions for neurological conditions including age-related dementias and learning disabilities in children. This project will also offer valuable training opportunities for undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to gain first hand experience in a cutting edge interdisciplinary study involving computer science, cognitive science, neurophysiology and neurology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

 

Episodic memories constitute the basic backbone of our identity. There has been extensive work evaluating memory formation under laboratory conditions where subjects are asked to memorize a list of words, or a collection of pictures. However, these laboratory tests fail to incorporate the critical components of real world memories, which include a narrative, emotional valence, spatiotemporal sequences, and rich multisensory information. Here we took significant strides towards elucidating the mechanisms that underlie episodic memory formation in close to real-life scenarios by combining behavioral experiments, neurophysiological recordings and machine-learning computational models. We performed systematic psychophysics experiments in close to 200 subjects to quantitatively measure how much people remember in movies or in real-life scenarios. We further proposed a machine learning computational model that is capable of predicting episodic memory formation, for individual subjects and individual trials from content information including visual, auditory and emotional features. In order to understand the neuronal mechanisms that subserve episodic memory formation, we conducted a series of invasive human neurophysiology experiments. Non-invasive measurements provide only an indirect and coarse picture of what happens inside the brain. To investigate the neurophysiological circuits, we collaborated with neurosurgeons who implant electrodes in patients with epilepsy for clinical purposes. This approach enables us to directly interrogate human brain function at high spatiotemporal resolution and with high signal-to-noise ratio. In one of these experiments, we showed that learning to form associations between visual stimuli and adequate behavioral responses is reflected in the moment-to-moment interactions between visual sensory cortical responses, motor cortical responses and frontal cortex circuits that map inputs to outputs. In a second experiment, we directly evaluated the neural correlates of the behavioral experiments examining memory formation for movie events. We found that we can predict which parts of movie events are more memorable based on the firing rate responses of neurons in the medial temporal lobe.

The research efforts were complemented by educational and training initiatives. We trained multiple undergraduate students and graduate students, who played a critical role in all of the research efforts. Two Harvard students received their Ph.D. as part of this effort. In addition, we welcomed and trained many undergraduate students from Harvard, MIT, Emmanuel College, Boston College, Northeastern University, and from other universities from around the world. The results of this work were presented in multiple conferences and shared through publications. We organized multiple workshops based on the work in this project. We also organized a yearly summer school in Woods Hole, MA, which included a group of 35 students each year, coming from all over the world, selected from a pool of more than 300 applicants. The data and open-source code are publicly shared through our web site and GitHub repositories.
